author: __lithp__
content: PLONKs/polynomial-commitments look really nice. The bigest drawback I can find is the trusted setup, but I don't think this would be such a big problem. What's stopping us from trying to adopt them? I guess it's unproven cryptography, does it take too long to generate witnesses?

author: pauld.9606
content:
An update for 0⇂\0߈\\ᘔ0ᘔ0 ;).

Aho's textbook chapter 4 explains how to define a syntax which is both unambiguous and efficient to parse. My goal is for the witness format to have both of these properties.

I started rewriting <@!520564582196969472>'s witness spec, deviating slightly, nothing major. The focus is no ambiguity and efficient parsing.

The most awkward part so far is enforcing that trees don't over-shoot the depth limit. I write these restrictions in plain English for now, because I don't want to introduce new notation.

For those who are both impatient and don't mind reading a work-in-progress, [here is a sneak preview of the witness spec rewrite](https://notes.ethereum.org/dfeV_C-pSI2h378AadR9DQ?view). I am happy with it so far, it is concise but dense. Not ready for pull request yet, and hackmd is easier for me to iterate on.

I need a break from reading Aho's textbook, so I will focus on the parser/generator implementation, and on the random witness generation tool.

I will give an update at the end of the week.

author: .vbuterin
content: <@456226577798135808> or anyone else, do you have stats on how long it takes to compute a poseidon hash?

author: Deleted User
content: I do not have such stats

author: .vbuterin
content: I guess doing it naively is basically the same as an elliptic curve multiplication

author: .vbuterin
content: And doing it with a ~100 MB lookup table would take 32 memory reads and 32 point additions (1/8 of a multiplication)

author: .vbuterin
content: So stats on how long it takes to do an ECMUL would be a good first approximation

author: .vbuterin
content: Basically, want to explore a third route toward eth1.x witness compression, which is using Poseidon hashes and then computing a SNARK or STARK over them
